In other words, $$$b_i = \\min \\limits_{j \\in [1, n], a_j \\ne a_i} |i - j|$$$.For example, if $$$a = [1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 3, 3, 1]$$$, then $$$b = [2, 1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 1, 1]$$$.Calculate the number of different arrays $$$b$$$ you can obtain if you consider all possible arrays $$$a$$$, and print it modulo $$$998244353$$$.InputThe only line of the input contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$k$$$ ($$$2 \\le n \\le 2 \\cdot 10^5$$$; $$$2 \\le k \\le \\min(n, 10)$$$).OutputPrint one integer â€” the number of different arrays $$$b$$$ you can obtain, taken modulo $$$998244353$$$.ExamplesInput2 2Output1Input4 3Output3Input6 2Output20Input6 5Output3Input133 7Output336975971

You are given two integers $n$ and $k$.  An array $a$ of length $n$ is constructed where each element is an integer from 1 to $k$.  Each integer from 1 to $k$ appears at least once in the array.

A new array $b$ is created based on $a$. For each element $a_i$ in $a$, the corresponding element $b_i$ is the smallest distance to another element in $a$ that is not equal to $a_i$.  

For example, if $a = [1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 3, 3, 1]$, then $b = [2, 1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 1, 1]$.

How many different arrays $b$ can be created by considering all possible arrays $a$?  Print the answer modulo 998244353.

You have an array of length *n* with elements from 1 to *k*.  Each number from 1 to *k* appears at least once.  

For each element in the array, find the distance to the nearest different element.  Count how many different arrays you can create with this rule and output the count modulo 998244353.
